Generation I.Red: Moves silently and stealthily. Eats the eggs of birds, such as Pidgey and Spearow , whole.
Generation I.Green: (This entry was originally untranslated in English until it was reused in Pokémon FireRed .)
Generation I.Blue: Moves silently and stealthily. Eats the eggs of birds, such as Pidgey and Spearow , whole.
Generation I.Yellow: The older it gets, the longer it grows. At night, it wraps its long body around tree branches to rest.
Generation I.Stadium: Slithers silently through grass, searching for its favorite food-- Pidgey and Spearow eggs.

Generation II.Gold: It can freely detach its jaw to swallow large prey whole. It can become too heavy to move, however.
Generation II.Silver: It always hides in grass. When first born, it has no poison, so its bite is painful, but harmless.
Generation II.Crystal: It flutters the tip of its tongue to seek out the scent of prey, then swallows the prey whole.
Generation II.Stadium 2: It can freely detach its jaw to swallow large prey whole. It can become too heavy to move, however. (Pokémon Red, Silver, or Crystal inserted) It always hides in grass. When first born, it has no poison, so its bite is painful, but harmless. (Pokémon Blue, Gold, or Yellow inserted)

Generation III.Ruby: Ekans curls itself up in a spiral while it rests. Assuming this position allows it to quickly respond to a threat from any direction with a glare from its upraised head.
Generation III.Sapphire: Ekans curls itself up in a spiral while it rests. Assuming this position allows it to quickly respond to a threat from any direction with a glare from its upraised head.
Generation III.Emerald: An Ekans curls itself up in a spiral while it rests. This position allows it to quickly respond to an enemy from any direction with a threat from its upraised head.
Generation III.FireRed: A very common sight in grassland, etc. It flicks its tongue in and out to sense danger in its surroundings.
Generation III.LeafGreen: Moving silently and stealthily, it eats the eggs of birds, such as Pidgey and Spearow , whole.

Generation IV.Diamond: It sneaks through grass without making a sound and strikes unsuspecting prey from behind.
Generation IV.Pearl: It sneaks through grass without making a sound and strikes unsuspecting prey from behind.
Generation IV.Platinum: It sneaks through grass without making a sound and strikes unsuspecting prey from behind.
Generation IV.HeartGold: It can freely detach its jaw to swallow large prey whole. It can become too heavy to move, however.
Generation IV.SoulSilver: It always hides in grass. When first born, it has no poison, so its bite is painful, but harmless.

Generation V.Black: It sneaks through grass without making a sound and strikes unsuspecting prey from behind.
Generation V.White: It sneaks through grass without making a sound and strikes unsuspecting prey from behind.
Generation V.Black 2: It sneaks through grass without making a sound and strikes unsuspecting prey from behind.
Generation V.White 2: It sneaks through grass without making a sound and strikes unsuspecting prey from behind.

Generation VI.X: The older it gets, the longer it grows. At night, it wraps its long body around tree branches to rest.
Generation VI.Y: Moving silently and stealthily, it eats the eggs of birds, such as Pidgey and Spearow, whole.
Generation VI.Omega Ruby: Ekans curls itself up in a spiral while it rests. Assuming this position allows it to quickly respond to a threat from any direction with a glare from its upraised head.
Generation VI.Alpha Sapphire: Ekans curls itself up in a spiral while it rests. Assuming this position allows it to quickly respond to a threat from any direction with a glare from its upraised head.

Generation VII.Ultra Sun: By dislocating its jaw, it can swallow prey larger than itself. After a meal, it curls up and rests.
Generation VII.Ultra Moon: The eggs of bird Pokémon are its favorite food. It swallows eggs whole, so sometimes an egg gets stuck, and Ekans faints.
Generation VII.Let's Go Pikachu: The older it gets, the longer it grows. At night, it wraps its long body around tree branches to rest.
Generation VII.Let's Go Eevee: The older it gets, the longer it grows. At night, it wraps its long body around tree branches to rest.

Generation VIII.Brilliant Diamond: It sneaks through grass without making a sound and strikes unsuspecting prey from behind.
Generation VIII.Shining Pearl: It sneaks through grass without making a sound and strikes unsuspecting prey from behind.

Generation IX.Scarlet: It can freely detach its jaw to swallow large prey whole. It can become too heavy to move, however.
Generation IX.Violet: A very common sight in grasslands and such. It flicks its tongue in and out to sense danger in its surroundings.

Generation II.Crystal: Routes 3 , 4 , 32 , 33 , and 42 Morning Day Routes 26 , 27 , 32 , 33 , and 42 , Azalea Town ( Headbutt trees )

Generation IV.HeartGold: Goldenrod Game Corner Safari Zone Morning Day (tall grass in Marshland, default)
Generation IV.SoulSilver: Routes 3 , 4 , 32 , and 33 Safari Zone Morning Day (tall grass in Marshland, default)

Generation VIII.Brilliant Diamond: Grand Underground - Grassland Cave , Swampy Cave , Riverbank Cave , Still-Water Cavern , Sunlit Cavern , Bogsunk Cavern (After obtaining the National Pokédex )

Generation IX.The Hidden Treasure of Area Zero: Kitakami Road , Apple Hills , Loyalty Plaza , Reveler's Road , Mossfell Confluence , Fellhorn Gorge , Oni Mountain , Wistful Fields Tera Raid Battles ( 1★ , 3★ )
